choices.B: destination MAC address and flush time
choices.D: destination MAC address and destination port
choices.C: source MAC address and source port
choices.A: source MAC address and aging time

questions.question_text: Which port type does a lightweight AP use to connect to the wired network when configured in FlexConnect mode with local switching and VLAN tagging?

discussion.content: Read full question

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

You can configure the LAN uplink interface of a FlexConnect AP as either an access port or as a trunk. If you configure the interface \as an access port, then the AP’s management traffic and all client traffic, whether centrally or locally switched, will be in the same VLAN. For security and reliability reasons, we recommend that you segregate the client traffic from the management VLAN, and so to configure the AP’s switchport as a trunk, with separately tagged VLANs for locally switched client traffic.

You can configure the LAN uplink interface of a FlexConnect AP as either an access port or as a trunk. If you configure the interface \as an access port, then the AP’s management traffic and all client traffic, whether centrally or locally switched, will be in the same VLAN. For security and reliability reasons, we recommend that you segregate the client traffic from the management VLAN, and so to configure the AP’s switchport as a trunk, with separately tagged VLANs for locally switched client traffic.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-5/config-guide/b_cg85/flexconnect.html#:~:text=You%20can%20configure%20the,locally%20switched%20client%20traffic.

When a lightweight access point (AP) is configured in FlexConnect mode with local switching and VLAN tagging, it typically uses a **trunk** port to connect to the wired network. This allows the AP to carry traffic for multiple VLANs, each identified by its VLAN tag.

So, the correct answer is:

A. **trunk**

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. PC A is communicating with another device at IP address 10.227.151.255. Through which router does router Y route the traffic?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
It is D because the destination IP address would be a broadcast address if router C is used.

Selected Answer: D
I definitely think this one wants the D.

Selected Answer: D
It‘s D

Selected Answer: D
This BGP entry for the 10.224.0.0/11 network is more specific to the destination IP address 10.227.151.255 than the 10.0.0.0/8 supernet and the 10.227.0.0/16 network. Since the /11 subnet mask encompasses IP addresses from 10.224.0.0 to 10.239.255.255, the destination IP address 10.227.151.255 falls within this range.

The next-hop IP address for this BGP route is 10.224.4.5, which corresponds to Router D.

The correct answer, taking into account the most specific route, is:

D. router D

Selected Answer: D
11100000 = 2^3 = 8 so 224 - 232 = 227 is included.

Selected Answer: D
10.227.151.255 is in 10.224.0.0/11

Selected Answer: D
Letter D

Refer to the exhibit. VoIP is being implemented in the network using VLAN ID 73 and named "VoIP". Each user needs a Cisco IP phone at their desk. Switchport e0/0 has been configured as an access port in the data VLAN. Cisco Discovery Protocol is enabled globally. Which command sequence completed the configuration?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct. IP phones are configured as access ports, with a separate voice VLAN.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D. vlan 73
name VoIP
e0/0
switchport voice vlan 73
